defaultSurfBreaks.name: Banzai Pipeline
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: If you are on a quest to find the legendary Banzai Pipeline Hawaii, known around the world  for its perfect barreling waves, then head to Ehukai Beach Park on the North Shore Oahu.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: If you are on a quest to find the legendary Banzai Pipeline Hawaii, known around the world  for its perfect barreling waves, then head to Ehukai Beach Park on the North Shore Oahu.If you are on a quest to find the legendary Banzai Pipeline Hawaii, known around the world  for its perfect barreling waves, then head to Ehukai Beach Park on the North Shore Oahu.If you are on a quest to find the legendary Banzai Pipeline Hawaii, known around the world  for its perfect barreling waves, then head to Ehukai Beach Park on the North Shore Oahu."

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Waikiki Beach
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: It was at the turn of the 20th century, on Waikiki Beach – the epicenter of life on Oahu – that Kahanamoku helped make surfing famous by offering lessons to visitors.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: (Fetched from https://traveltips.usatoday.com/famous-surfing-beaches-hawaii-107162.html)It was at the turn of the 20th century, on Waikiki Beach – the epicenter of life on Oahu – that Kahanamoku helped make surfing famous by offering lessons to visitors. That tradition continues to this day, thanks to calm waters that make it easy for beginners to try their hand – or feet, rather – at the sport. Sign up for lessons at the one of the booths on the beach and commemorate the occasion by posing for a photo with the famous statue of Kahanamoku.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Army Beach
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Army Beach is located on Oahu's northwestern shore, across from the entrance to the Dillingham Airfield
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Army Beach is located on Oahu's northwestern shore, across from the entrance to the Dillingham Airfield. It is near the end of Farrington Highway and at the beginning of the Ka'ena Point State Park. The beach is backed by the Waianae Mountains and is quite scenic. It is a long, sandy beach with azure blue waters. The ocean bottom is mainly rocky with a coral reef, but there is a small reef-free area that's ideal for a dip into the ocean if you would like to swim. Surfing is also possible here. In the winter months (November to March), the waves can reach heights of 15+ feet (4.5+ m), so this is no time for swimming. When the surf is up, strong currents make entering the ocean too dangerous.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Polo Beach
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: If you are on a quest to find the legendary Polo Beach Hawaii, known around the world  for its perfect barreling waves, then head to Ehukai Beach Park on the North Shore Oahu.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: (Fetched form https://www.to-hawaii.com/oahu/beaches/armybeach.php)If you are on a quest to find the legendary Banzai Pipeline Hawaii, known around the world  for its perfect barreling waves, then head to Ehukai Beach Park on the North Shore Oahu.If you are on a quest to find the legendary Banzai Pipeline Hawaii, known around the world  for its perfect barreling waves, then head to Ehukai Beach Park on the North Shore Oahu.If you are on a quest to find the legendary Banzai Pipeline Hawaii, known around the world  for its perfect barreling waves, then head to Ehukai Beach Park on the North Shore Oahu."
defaultSurfBreaks.address: ess: '59-337 Ke Nui Rd, Haleiwa, HI 96712

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Haleʻiwa Beach
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Adjacent to the Hotel Haleiwa, but hid away behind a grove of Pride of India trees, fragrant at the time of our visit from the delicate odor of its profuse lilac flowers
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Adjacent to the Hotel Haleiwa, but hid away behind a grove of Pride of India trees, fragrant at the time of our visit from the delicate odor of its profuse lilac flowers, is the old Emerson mission homestead, now being demolished, showing quaint features in its structure of pioneer days. Near the old house is the never-failing spring, Kawaipuolo, of legendary fame, which furnishes water to the hotel. Not far from this point, but across the Anahulu stream, stand the ruins of Waialua’s Female Seminary, prominent in this line of missionary work under the Gulicks and the late Mary Green, and the original “Haleiwa” of this place, which name the hotel has appropriately adopted. After the first American Protestant missionaries arrived in 1820, they began establishing stations in the rural areas of O’ahu. The first of these was the Waialua Station, opened in July 1832 by John S. Emerson and his wife. They lived on the bank of Anahulu Stream where Emerson continued his missionary work until 1864, when he retired because of ill health. He died at his home in 1867.
defaultSurfBreaks.address: ess: '59-337 Ke Nui Rd, Haleiwa, HI 96712

defaultSurfBreaks.name: PUA’ENA POINT
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Located on Oahu's North Shore next to Haleiwa Beach Park, Pua'ena Point (see more photos, view panorama) is mainly known among the local surf crowd for being a good surf spot
defaultSurfBreaks.description:
Fetched from https://www.to-hawaii.com/oahu/beaches/ Located on Oahu's North Shore next to Haleiwa Beach Park, Pua'ena Point (see more photos, view panorama) is mainly known among the local surf crowd for being a good surf spot.It can be a good spot for beginners when the waves aren't too high. Surfing lessons take place here. But when the surf is way up, it's for experts only. Most surfers enter the ocean from a small sandy beach before reaching Pua'ena Point.

The beach is a nice place for a picnic (there is some shade), and on the weekends local families come here with their children. The nearshore ocean bottom is a mixture of rocks and small sand patches. If you walk further along the shoreline (about three minutes), you'll reach Pua'ena Point (a rocky outcropping). Around the corner is Police Beach, where episodes of the popular TV series LOST were filmed.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Kaena Point
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Located on Oahu's North Shore next to Kaena Point, Kaena Point (see more photos, view panorama) is mainly known among the local surf crowd for being a good surf spot
defaultSurfBreaks.description:
Fetched from https://www.to-hawaii.com/oahu/beaches/ Located on Oahu's North Shore next to Haleiwa Beach Park, Pua'ena Point (see more photos, view panorama) is mainly known among the local surf crowd for being a good surf spot.It can be a good spot for beginners when the waves aren't too high. Surfing lessons take place here. But when the surf is way up, it's for experts only. Most surfers enter the ocean from a small sandy beach before reaching Pua'ena Point.

The beach is a nice place for a picnic (there is some shade), and on the weekends local families come here with their children. The nearshore ocean bottom is a mixture of rocks and small sand patches. If you walk further along the shoreline (about three minutes), you'll reach Pua'ena Point (a rocky outcropping). Around the corner is Police Beach, where episodes of the popular TV series LOST were filmed.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Gas Chambers
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Gas Chambers is a fast, hollow and shallow point break type of wave. It is a high performance wave that is well-suited for the average to pro level surfer.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Fetched from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gas_Chambers# Gas Chambers is a beach located on the North Shore of Oahu about a 1/4 of a mile north of Ehukai Beach Park and 1/2 a mile west of Sunset Beach Park

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Rocky Point
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Rocky's is generally divided into two sections known as Rocky Rights and Rocky Lefts, but within those are several different takeoff points in different conditions.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Rocky Point is a flat, curving reef that is about 250-yards wide and perhaps the most consistent wave on the North Shore, breaking up to double overhead-plus on nearly any winter swell direction. Rocky's somehow satisfies even its most frightening crowds with a range of waves -- from soft walls to clean barrels to crazy air sections.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Rocky Point Lefts
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Rocky Point Lefts in Oahu is an exposed beach and reef break that has very consistent surf, although summer tends to be mostly flat.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Fetched from https://surfing-waves.com/ One of the most consistent waves on the North Shore. Best from chest to overhead. Gets busy during the winter swells.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Backdoor
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Backdoor. Sometimes Backdoor Pipe, but usually just Backdoor. Same break, two names, and it occurs to me that this is odd, possibly unique.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Fetched from https://www.surfline.com/ Backdoor was somewhat ignored during Pipeline's first golden days in the 1970s. It makes you wonder how many heaving barrels roared right off the peak before everyone kind of clicked on it. The wave relies on a slight breaking up of swell lines from the northwest (shorter to mid period swells are best, of a swell combo) and a thin channel between the Pipe reef and Off-The-Wall. The broken swell allows a tapering wall, which hits square on the shallowest part of first reef and creates an intense and very hollow, deep tube

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Off the Wall
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: As close to a hoax as any famous wave of the past 30 years, Off-The-Wall (OTW) is a single slab of reef just to the west of Backdoor and Pipeline.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Fetched from https://www.surfline.com/ OTW is separated from the Backdoor reef by a narrow, deep crevice, which blocks some swells from closing out across both breaks. The OTW reef is largely flat lava, with a mound of shallower reef near its northern edge. It is best in a slightly fractured, overhead NW swell. It's a wedging right, with some smaller lefts peeling back toward Backdoor. On precisely the right wave, OTW will produce a beautiful almond-shaped barrel; many waves will be caught and ridden to closeout point by the hopeful surfer before that ideal one is found.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Rockpile
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Rockpile is located between Log Cabins and Off-The-Wall
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Fetched from https://www.surfline.com/ This spot offers a big, powerful left that is best on the more NW to WNW angled swells, and a right on the more northerly angled swells. During a more northerly angled swell, this spot is a magnet, pulling in more size than any spot around. During big swells, it's not uncommon for Kam Hwy to get washed out at this spot.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Waimea Bay
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: The birthplace of big wave surfing
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Fetched from https://www.surfline.com/ Rideable waves first begin to break when the surf climbs into the overhead to double overhead-plus zone on a section known as Pinballs -- a lumpy reef almost parallel with the tip of the Bay's north point that can be fun on clean NW swells with a light tradewind blowing. As the swell grows beyond 3-4 times overhead, waves begin to peak and break just inside a big boil 80 yards out past Pinballs, providing a drop, a fat shoulder and some reform shots further in. As the surf increases further, waves will starting breaking on the shallower regions of the true Waimea takeoff area

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Chun's
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: The surf site Chun’s Reef was named for John Chun, a former resident of Kawailoa
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Fetched from https://www.hawaiibeachsafety.com/ Chun’s Reef Support Park is a small undeveloped parcel of land owned by the City and County of Honolulu on the inland side of Kamehameha Highway at Chun’s Reef. Surfers cross the wide sand beach fronting the park to reach several surf sites besides Chun’s Reef, including Pidleys and Jocko’s

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Jockos
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Named after North Shore legend Jock Sutherland
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Jocko's is a worthy left reef pointbreak, offering up a relatively easy takeoff compared to its higher profile North Shore counterparts and long rides. But don't be fooled into complacency -- when a big WNW-NW swell fills in, Jocko's transforms into a proper, heavy left barrel. Also, at this size, the current here is notoriously vicious

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Turtle Bay
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Turtle Bay East and West are Located at Turtle Bay Resort on North Shore Oahu
defaultSurfBreaks.description: It used to be a haven from the North Shore crush, but during the winter months these days, the right breaking in the shadow of the colossus Turtle Bay Resort on the eastern edge of Kawela Bay is a bonafide surfing hotspot. Though considered mellow by North Shore standards, Turtle Bay West can get really good on a proper N swell, even offering up some worthy barrel sections. Meanwhile, around the peninsula and on the east side of the resort, Turtle Bay East turns on during a proper N or NW swell

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Makaha
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Makaha in Oahu is an exposed beach and reef break that has reliable surf and can work at any time of the year.
defaultSurfBreaks.description:
Makaha is a reer and beach break that is well exposed to westerly swells, providing consistent surf. The waves break left and right over the reefs and on the beach breaks.
The break can hold huge swells, during the winter months the surf can reach 25 feet on the point, providing some of the most challenging surfing in the whole of Hawaii.
It does get crowded here so take care.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Tracks
defaultSurfBreaks.summary:
Find tracks beach just north of the power plant. Best throughout the winter on a west or north swell. Best at any size up to head high.
Nice beach.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Tracks(Nanakuli) in Oahu is an exposed beach and reef break that has consistent surf and can work at any time of the year. Offshore winds are from the northeast. Groundswells more frequent than windswells and the ideal swell angle is from the west. A choice of left and right reefs. Sometimes crowded. Take care of sharks

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Yokohama Bay
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: If fellow West Side spot Makaha is classic Oahu in the historical sense, Yokohama Bay, just fifteen minutes up Farrington Highway, is classic Oahu in the natural sense.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Yokohama Bay in Oahu is an exposed beach break that has very consistent surf and works all around the year. Offshore winds are from the east northeast. Clean groundswells prevail and the ideal swell direction is from the west northwest. A left hand reef break. When the surf is up, it can get quite busy in the water. Beware of rips, rocks and locals.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Ma'ili
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: There are a couple of fun wave options on the 40-acre Ma'ili Beach Park. The two prominent breaks are called Green Lanterns and Tumbleland
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Ma'ili Point in Oahu is an exposed reef and point break that usually has waves and can work at any time of the year. Offshore winds are from the east northeast. Clean groundswells prevail and the ideal swell direction is from the west northwest. A left hand reef break. A fairly popular wave that can sometimes get crowded Beware of sharks and rocks.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Barber's Point
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Good surf spot for beginners, White Sands is a very nice break, with easy waves. Safe swimming for keiki
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Barbers Point picks up Southern Hemi swells from all directions, and it can also absorb Northern Hemi energy that has a lot of W in it (between 390-329 degrees) or has snuck under Ni'ihau and Kauai (under 285 degrees). There is a point wave that breaks directly out beyond the lighthouse, but there are a variety of peaks spread out down the beach that offer good surf, depending on swell direction. Due to Barbers Point's exposed location, wind is often a factor.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Ewa Beach
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Ewa Beach is located just west of Pearl Harbor and offers up a variety of smaller wave options, from lefts to rights, barrels to shoulders. Like Barbers Point eight miles to the west, Ewa Beach is wind-sensitive.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Ewa Beach Park in Oahu is an exposed reef break that has quite reliable surf and can work at any time of the year. The best wind direction is from the north northwest. Groundswells and windswells are equally likely and the ideal swell direction is from the south southeast. Reef breaks provide lefts and rights. It's sometimes crowded here. Watch out for rocks.
defaultSurfBreaks.address: 91-050 Fort Weaver Rd. Ewa Beach, HI 96706

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Sand Island
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Despite its proximity to Town, Sand Island is often one of the best places to beat the crowds -- seems almost hidden in plain sight. There are a few different peaks to choose from that offer both rights and lefts. Water quality is often suspect with harbor entrances on each side, one of which leads to a large industrial harbor. This spot is known for shark sightings as well, following commercial fishing boats going into the harbor.
defaultSurfBreaks.description: Sand Island is an arid, urban coastal park which offers picnicking, camping, walking, shore fishing and board surfing. It fronts a small sand beach and has good views of Honolulu Harbor and ocean sunsets.

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Jockos
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Named after North Shore legend Jock Sutherland

defaultSurfBreaks.name: Jockos
defaultSurfBreaks.summary: Named after North Shore legend Jock Sutherland
